displayed_text: Patient: And that’s for real. Doctor: Alright, sir, and, uh- Patient: And so it’s, it’s, when you say it got into something, well, did they take it out? Doctor: Yeah. We took it, we took it out. Yeah. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Right. It was, it was out of the prostate into the seminal vesicle which structurally comes off of the prostate. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We removed it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it was going into it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then the question is, did it go from there elsewhere?

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s been tried; even the addition of chemotherapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yet it prolongs the recurrence, but it still doesn’t prevent the recurrence or prevent it recurring. Healthcare Professional: But then there’s therapies that happen. Doctor: Right. That’s one of the last options Healthcare Professional: Yeah, yeah, there are other therapies for when that happens. Family Member: Aside from hormones. Healthcare Professional: So they stay on the hormones. Family Member: Oh. Healthcare Professional: So he stays on the hormones but then we add to it. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Either a second-line hormone like he was talking about that they’re looking at this trial using it earlier.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: There’s lymph nodes all along there. So at different places uh- Patient: Are there new ones or it’s the same ones that are just enlarged? I mean- Doctor: It looks like the same ones have enlarged a bit. Patient: So what, so what does that tell us? Doctor: Well, it’s confusing because some are actually smaller. Uh up in the chest. So one for instance was point nine centimeters. Now it’s point six. And one was uh, uh. That’s actually a little bigger. Uh but the ones in the abdomen and lower down have all gotten bigger. So for the most part by a few millimeters. Patient: Hum. Doctor: So but enough change that, that I think we’re probably not going in the- Patient: In the right direction. Doctor: In the right direction. So I think you know we didn’t get much response to the enzalutamide or that. It sounds, it seems like your cancer may just not be hormonally sensitive at this point. Patient: Okay. Doctor: To kind of go both ways, a low hormone, high hormone.

Patient: Okay. Let me, let me ask this here, doc. Doctor: Yes? Patient: So, what is this trial that you’re talkin’ about? Doctor: Okay. Patient: Tell me more. Doctor: Doc This is – you’ve had the XTANDI. Patient: Right. Doctor: It’s sorta breaking through, right? You’re cancer’s already sort of figured out how it works. Patient: Right. Doctor: You’re options are A different standard of care pill, but we worry that if you go from that pill to the other pill, we don’t get a lot of mileage out of that because it’s too similar. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So then we could talk about chemo. (Pause)

Patient: Yeah nothing complicated. Doctor: Nothing complicated. Family Member 1: Flush twice. Doctor: Nothing complicated. Family Member 2: He’s wiping the toilet, but he’s also wiping the sink with a separate wipe. Doctor: He’s wiping the toilet. So kind of like where you're at, just swipe around it and then when everything blows up, boom in here. Good. Good. Family Member 1: And so when he washes his hands? Doctor: Doc Same thing. Patient: Pat Yeah. Family Member 2: What about her mom? A____’s two. Her mom. She's pregnant. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: Can he be around her? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, as long as she’s not sick. Come on M___. Come in here smells so good.

Patient: I'm the lazy investor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah, the lazy, you know retirement guy. Doctor: Sometimes you can like sign up early for Medicare, because you've got health issues. Those are things we got to get straight before. Yeah. And then Medicare is not all just Medicare, Medicare has dashes attached to Medicare. Some of it is the prescription plan that you need to have. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So those are things you got to get straight before you do anything else. So we're going to be in deep doo doo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: When it comes to trials, if it's something like, oh, give this new pill to get we give that to you. We don't bill the insurance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But that Xtandi, we still have to do what we got to do. Obviously, we're gonna support you in any which way we can. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But yeah, before anything drastic happens, and if you sometimes want to just talk to social work about what is the next step, they can guide you there too. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yes and I like that. During the day see what. Doctor: Yeah, you just see how it, and then, you know, when you take this don’t drive, Patient: Right. Right Doctor: don’t do, I mean and literally don’t drive heavy machinery. Patient: Yeah, I don’t. Doctor: The number of times I’ve had to say that. Wait, so I can’t go out there and work on the tractor? Patient: Right. No. Doctor: No, no, no, right, because you don’t know how you’re going to react. Most people just get sleepy and want to take a nap and then they feel better but everyone’s different. Okay? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Make a copy of this and then. Oh yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Is Provenge off the table? Doctor: Provenge is off the table in the sense that your PSA is um too high I think but more importantly that you have pain. You know, Provenge is good with, it’s kind of like your asymptomatic, you’re doing great, you have a couple spots, your PSA is less than thirty. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Um the reality is that we have tried that in the past and we still do that on occasion in certain patients. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: All the lymph nodes are connected to each other by so-called lymphatic system - Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and so the the the concern about targeting one particular lymph node or maybe two lymph nodes or three lymph nodes is is that um you might only be affecting you know ten percent, fifteen percent, thirty percent of the cancer cells in your body. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So you’re going after them just because you can see it but there is no guarantee that what we can see on the CAT scan is the only place at this point in time where the cancer is at. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: So we might graph that lymph node and your PSA might drop by fifteen percent, then we’ll know in retrospect had we got that lymph node we might have actually killed all of the cells in that lymph node - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and yet your PSA might drop by fifteen or twenty-five percent. And so what we’ve learnt the hard way, so-to-speak with experience, is that although we can do that, it is technically feasible -um and there are some types of radiation that can be reimbursed by insurance companies, for example -

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we don’t, I don’t think that’s part of their indication. Um, but, you know, we’d have to ask the proton guys for that. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Well then being that the radiation is site specific Doctor: Mm Mmm. Patient: and you’ve created this area- Doctor: Yep. Patient: Why wouldn’t we go site specific in all the other areas that I have- Family Member: You don’t want too much. Too much will kill ya’. Patient: -that you have imaging to know where it is? Doctor: Well, because it doesn’t change the outcome. So your treatment is so that the pain gets better as in kill the cells, no pain. If you have pain elsewhere, you could consider that. But if it’s just a pluck off the areas that you think has cancer, it doesn’t change the overall status of your disease. You know? You don’t live longer with it but you might get some down sides. You know? Like she said the more you radiate the more your bone marrow is hit. So you’ll get a consequence off of that where you might lose some cells. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So you don’t want to treat them unless you know what you’re going to get a result of. So with radiation right now the result is gee I hope my pain is controlled. That’s what I wanted for you. The second one would be gee I hope my pain is controlled and my spine gets stabilized. Whew. And then number three would be I hope the cancer doesn’t come back there. You know? Now it’s been burned out.

Patient: For-? Doctor: Four doses. Patient: For, for, for what’s that? Doctor: Unclear, depending on how you tolerate. You know? We can back off or- Patient: Six, six months? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: About four months. Okay. Patient: I know, I, yeah, no, I’d like to go and see if I have it or not because that would be another option I could possibly go to Europe or wherever and have them do it, if I know it’s going to help. If it’s not going to help, I don’t want to go over there. Doctor: No. I agree. So, but that would mean you would sign up for the study if they’re going to do the scan. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So you’re okay with that? Patient: Yeah. Yeas. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And on a clinical trial, we don’t know if more is better, but that third drug, if you were to get it, starts to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: If you don’t get it- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - you still have two things that we know kill cancer cells that make people live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so do we just sort of like stay low or if you get better, if the prostate shrinks and we are able to get the catheter out, then we did the right thing. Or if time goes on and you still have trouble getting that catheter out, uh would radiation help? Is it because the drugs aren’t doing what they need to do to shrink it to allow you to have a reasonable channel to get the pee out? Um and that’s sort of – before when we had chemo and before we had these super hormones, some of us would send you to radiation. And then now we don’t know because you can’t get the radiation and the chemo and the hormone all at the same time. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Because that’s just way too much. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Now, is he going to have a body scan at one point to see what’s happening with the cancer cells? Uh she should have that body scan uh that Dr. ____ said that it’s . Now is it down the road? Is it something that you plan to do or does it matter? Or how would you know that the cancer is shrinking? Patient: That the cancer is shrinking.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they will likely shrink the disease and, you know, also lower the PSA, and the good thing is they are likely to work for long periods of time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, the possibility of side effects is a little bit higher. Okay? And usually, those side effects are high blood pressure, leg swelling, low potassium. So, you’re going to have to monitor and stay with the visits because at least for the first few months, we’ll have to monitor you somewhat closer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Once both of us sort of get comfortable, like we did, but you got too comfortable, Doctor: With this medication Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Then, I will be able to space it further and further apart. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the first two or three months are going to be somewhat critical. Patient: The same what we did with the Casodex? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: No. Doctor: Swelling? Bumps, Lumps? Patient: No. No. Family Member: Are those, uh, energy drinks that you see on TV problematic? I’m asking sort of for myself, too. Doctor: Uh. I mean they have a lot of calories in them, and so, uh, it’s more about why he’s takin’ them or Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: I mean, again, if he takes them, he may eat less, but – um. Family Member: Are they just loaded with caffeine or something or? Doctor: Some of them are. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, when we saw you or you had came on April seventeenth, your white count was normal. You are anemic. I don’t think it’s really the iron. It may be your cancer and your treatment. It’s twenty-nine. Normal would be forty-one. Uh, and your platelets are okay. So, the only thing that we see is the low, uh, blood count, blood cells. Um. Your liver looks good. (Pause) Patient: I was on chemo ‘til February? Maybe that’s why the blood count’s down. I don’t know. (Pause)

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It almost would require us putting you back on it, having demonstrated it doesn’t work, and then adding this drug, which is kind of weird. Occasionally, however, we have seen men after testosterone because potentially you could respond to enzalutamide. I don’t know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s a little bit confusing but that’s another possible trial. Patient: That’s the extent, enzalutamide? Doctor: Yeah, right. So I mean you didn’t respond. Patient: Well I mean the, the PSA went up a little bit. It went from- Doctor: With the scans. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh and the third trial we have which is the most extreme one, we’re also doing bone marrow transplant trial, which um is way out there. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh we have two men we’ve treated now, your age or younger. Uh that would require you to live here for a couple of months, and it would require a donor, a female, like a daughter, or sister, or cousin.

Patient: Right. Doctor: that way I know when you started. When you’ve been on it for two or three weeks, you come back to see me and we’ll make sure you’re doing okay. Patient: When I’m doing okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So now okay you know what my next question is… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know I got that motorcycle. Doctor: I know. Family Member: Please stop. Didn’t I tell you to stay off that motorcycle? Patient: You didn’t tell me to stay off my motorcycle. Family Member: From the last time we were here, I’ve told him to stop being on that motorcycle. Doctor: Well we worry about you being on that motorcycle. You know that. I know it’s what you love. You love being on that motorcycle but I worry about the way your back is and all this stuff. I just worry about it. Patient: Okay. Okay so here’s the deal.
